Detailed Description

template<int numJoints> template class DefaultTrajectoryGenerator

Creates a trajectory along queued target points.

This class implements a trajectory generator that creates a smooth trajectory along points specified by the user. Points can be specified in Cartesian coordinates or joint coordinates. All points are stored in a queue and used in first-in first-out (FIFO) order. If there is only one point left in the queue, the trajectory generator plans a deceleration and stop at this point. If there is more than one point in the queue, the trajectory generator uses the current point as a via point and blends the last motion segment with the new motion segment to allow for a smooth transition.

Note that only one thread at a time may use the functions of the DefaultTrajectoryGenerator object at a time.

Example Program: 

//======================================================================== 
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
// Package: Trajectory Generator
// Authors: Markus Loffler
// Start Date: Tue Apr 17 13:06:22 GMT 2001
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------  
// File: DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.t.cpp
// Example program for the class DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "RoboticPlatform.hpp"
#include "DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.hpp"
#include "Vector.hpp"
#include "ObjectManager.hpp"
 
 
//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
  RoboticPlatform::setStartSceneViewerOff();
  RoboticPlatform::init(argc, argv);
  
  DefaultTrajectoryGenerator<2> tragen;
  tragen.createControlPanel();
  tragen.setBlockingMovesOff();
    
  Vector<2> a;
  
  a = 0.1, 0.2;
  cout << "Move to " << transpose(a) << endl;
  tragen.move(a);
  
  a = -0.1, 0;
  cout << "Move to " << transpose(a) << endl;
  MotionId id = tragen.move(a);
  
  cout << "Stop" << endl;
  tragen.stop(0.5);

  a = 0.7, 0.5;
  cout << "Move to " << transpose(a) << endl;
  tragen.setBlendingTime(0.5);
  tragen.move(a);

  cout << "Stop" << endl;
  tragen.stop(3);

  a = 0, 0.4;
  cout << "Move to " << transpose(a) << endl;
  tragen.move(a);
  
  tragen.waitForRequestCompleted(id);
  cout << "Point -0.1, 0.2 reached!" << endl;

  tragen.waitForLastRequestCompleted();

  sleep(10);

  RoboticPlatform::exit();
  
  return 0;
}

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

DefaultTrajectoryGenerator ( const char * objectName )
 

This constructor allows you to specify the object name. If the section in the global configuration file specified by the object name has the class name "DefaultTrajectoryGenerator", then the settings of this section are used to setup the object.

Parameters:
objectName   Object name, identical with the section name in the global configuration file.

DefaultTrajectoryGenerator ( int numInConfig = 1 )
 

This constructor allows you to specify the number of the object in the global configuration file that specifies the class name "DefaultTrajectoryGenerator". The settings of this object in the global configuration are used to setup the object.

Parameters:
numInConfig   Number of the object in the global configuration file (only objects of the correct class type are counted), starting at "1".

The constructor initializes class variables. This constructor is only called from a derived class.

Member Function Documentation

void localInit ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function is called from all constructors. It does the actual class initialization.

void setBlockingMovesOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Sets the blocking mode such that calls of the "move" function block until the movement is complete (the trajectory generator has reached the queued point).

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setBlockingMovesOff ( ) [virtual]
 

Sets the blocking mode such that calls of the "move" function return immediately.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isBlockingMovesOn ( ) [virtual]
 

Determines if the blocking mode is enabled for move() commands.

Returns:
true: Blocking mode is enabled
false: Blocking mode is not enabled.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void waitForLastRequestCompleted ( ) [virtual]
 

Waits (blocks) until the trajectory generator has reached the last target point (The motion queue is empty after that).

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void waitForRequestCompleted ( MotionId motionId ) [virtual]
 

Waits (blocks) until the movement to a certain queued motion point has been completed.

Parameters:
motionId   Specifies the motion point (this value is returned by the move commands).

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

int getNumRequestsInQueue ( ) [virtual]
 

Determines the number of motion requests that are queued.

Returns:
Number of queued motion requests.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setJointInterpolationMode ( ) [virtual]
 

Sets the joint interpolation mode. In this mode, the trajectory from current position to a target or via point is calculated via interpolating the joint coordinates of these positions. This mode avoids singularities during the motion to the target position and hence, is safer than the Cartesian interpolation mode. The selected interpolation mode is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isJointInterpolationMode ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines if the joint interpolation mode is selected.

Returns:
true: The joint interpolation mode is selected.
false: A different interpolation mode is selected.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setCartesianInterpolationMode ( ) [virtual]
 

Sets the Cartesian interpolation mode. In this mode, the trajectory from current position to a target or via point is calculated via interpolating the Cartesian coordinates of these positions. The selected interpolation mode is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

This function currently fails and sets d_objectStatus to error since Cartesian interpolation mode is not implemented.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isCartesianInterpolationMode ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines if the Cartesian interpolation mode is selected.

Returns:
true: The Cartesian interpolation mode is selected.
false: A different interpolation mode is selected.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setJointVelocityLimit ( const VectorBase<>& velocityLimit ) [virtual]
 

Sets the maximum velocity for each joint. Note that the final velocity limits are determined by multiplying this value with the speed scale factor. The selected velocity limits are used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

The velocity limits are updated with the default velocity limits of the manipulator whenever the trajectory generator is connected to a manipulator.

Parameters:
velocityLimit   The maximum velocity joint vector. Each element of this vector is in degrees/sec (revolute joint) or meters/sec (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void getJointVelocityLimit ( VectorBase<>& velocityLimit ) [virtual]
 

Gets the maximum velocity for each joint.

Parameters:
velocityLimit   The current velocity limit joint vector.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setSpeedScale ( double speedScale ) [virtual]
 

Sets the speed scale to a new value. The speed scale is a factor that is multiplied with the velocity limits before they are used. Hence, setting the speed scale is a handy way to quickly set the trajectory generator to different overall speeds. The selected speed scale is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

Parameters:
speedScale   The new speed scale.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

double getSpeedScale ( ) const [virtual]
 

Determines the current speed scale.

Returns:
The current value of the speed scale.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

void setBlendingTime ( double blendingTime ) [virtual]
 

Sets the blending time to a new value. The selected blending time is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

Parameters:
blendingTime   The new blending time.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

double getBlendingTime ( ) [virtual]
 

Determines the current blending time.

Returns:
The current blending time.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( const Transform & endEffectorTransform ) [virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point, specified by an end-effector transform. Note that this function might fail if there is no inverse kinematics implemented for the specified manipulator, or no manipulator is connected to the trajectory generator.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_objectStatus is set to error.

Parameters:
endEffectorTransform   The end-effector transform to queue.
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Examples: 

     DefaultTrajectoryGenerator tragen;
    
     // Move the end-effector to a certain Cartesian position.
     tragen.move(translation(0, 20, 0) * xRotation(30));

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( VectorBase<>& jointEndPosition ) [virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point, specified by a vector that contains a joint position for each joint.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_objectStatus is set to error.

Parameters:
jointEndPosition   The joint vector of the target/via point to queue, each joint position is in degrees (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( int jointNumber,
double position ) [virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point that has the same joint coordinates as the last queued point except a specfied joint coordinate that has a different value.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_objectStatus is set to error.

Parameters:
jointNumber   Joint that has the new position (0 = first joint).
position   The new position, in degrees (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Examples: 

     DefaultTrajectoryGenerator tragen;
    
     // Move the first joint to 90 degrees.
     tragen.move(0, 90);

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId stop ( double stopTime ) [virtual]
 

Queues a stop request. This stop request, when taken out of the queue, causes a deceleration in the trajectory, until a complete stop (constant setpoint) for a certain time.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_objectStatus is set to error.

Parameters:
stopTime   Stop time, includes deceleration time.

Reimplemented from QueueTrajectoryGenerator.

bool getCurrentSetpoint ( VectorBase<>& setpointJoint,
Transform & setpointCartesian,
int & configuration ) [virtual]
 

Returns the current setpoint in either joint coordinates or Cartesian coordinates. The return value specifies in which coordinate system the setpoint is. Note: for generic programming, createJointVector() can be used to create a vector that is big enough to fit the setpoint in joint coordinates.

Parameters:
setpointJoint   The current setpoint in joint coordinates.
setpointCartesian   The current setpoint in Cartesian coordinates.
configuration   The configuration of the robot (only provided with Cartesian setpoint).
Returns:
true: The current setpoint is in Cartesian coordinates, setpointCartesian is valid, false: The current setpoint is in joint coordinates, setpointJoint is valid.

Reimplemented from TrajectoryGenerator.

void reset ( Manipulator * manipulator = 0 ) [virtual]
 

This function initializes the trajectory generator with the current manipulator position and do other initalization (e.g., reinitialize the motion queue).

Note: If multiple manipulators connect to the same trajectory generator, the settings of the last manipulator that connected will be used.

Parameters:
manipulator   A pointer to the associated manipulator, 0 if no manipulator is associated.

Reimplemented from TrajectoryGenerator.

double getCurrentSetpointSamplePeriod ( ) [virtual]
 

This function returns the sampling period of the trajectory generation.

Returns:
The maximum expected setpoint sample period.

Reimplemented from TrajectoryGenerator.

VectorBase * createJointVector ( ) [virtual]
 

Creates a vector that has the correct size to fit all joint coordinates in it. The vector is dynamically allocated and needs to be freed with "delete".

Returns:
A pointer to the new vector.

Reimplemented from TrajectoryGenerator.

int enterControl ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function is called when the control program is loaded.

Returns:
0: Loading the control was successful, Non-Zero: Error occurred in enterControl().

int control ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function is called every control cycle at a frequency specified by the data member d_controlFrequency.

Returns:
0: Continue control execution, Non-Zero: terminate control execution (stopControl() will still be called)

int stopControl ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function is called when the control stops

Returns:
